A few controversial things I believe about Solopreneurship.

1) It's not as difficult as you think.

Iâ€™m not saying it's easy to start building your own business.

Iâ€™m just saying that the core fundamentals are some knowledge, a landing page, a way to collect a payment, and the courage to talk about it daily.

-

2) You don't need to work 60-80 hours per week

Contrary to popular belief, the 24/7 successful hustle bro is a myth.

I've seen it firsthand.

- Burnout
- Fake riches
- Happy outside, sh  * tty inside.

Hustling is necessary sometimes.

Hustle 24/7 is a fast track to misery.

-

3) You don't need to be ruthless or transactional

99% of the time, acting this way is a giant mistake.

Instead, try these things, which allow you to be successful without being an a  *   * hole.

- Build a tight circle of real friends
- Provide value daily to each other and others
- Help them achieve their goals and grow together

Recognize who helped you get there and say yes to those folks often.

When someone doesn't make an effort to build a real relationship, say a polite "no".

You can't be everything to everyone, but you don't have to be a jerk either.

-

4) Money matters, but it's not the "be-all, end-all".

Pursuing as much money as possible is a silly goal.

Because money doesn't create joy.

It can certainly be helpful in creating many, many moments of fleeting happiness, but a happy life isn't what I'm after.

My pursuit in life is about joy:

- Having purpose
- Having community
- Helping other people

You can do all of that without $10M or $50M or $100M.

-

I hope this helps dispel a few myths about building a one-person business.

There's never been a better time to get started.

Most new managers think that becoming a manager is the â€œgraduation.â€ Truth is, itâ€™s the reverse.

When you go from being someone who â€œexecutesâ€ to someone whoâ€™s managing a team, you go from trading on IQ to trading on EQ. 

You go from doing the actual work to listening to employees, catering to what they want, taking blame, and being the bigger person.

Remember, leaders work for their employees.

The best leaders and CEOs are empathetic.

Why? They understand that itâ€™s about more than being a caring person, itâ€™s about taking your understanding of another person or group of people and using it to create a win-win scenario.

Itâ€™s also important to balance empathy with letting people learn things on their own, especially in a business context.

For example, when two of my employees have a disagreement or conflict, I might intuitively know the answers to what would improve or fix the situation. That being said, I still want to give them the opportunity to figure it out for themselves.

If you're 22, 25, 30, and you think you should have your whole career path figured out, that's ludicrous. 

When you're this young, the number one thing you should do is the most high risk behavior of your life. The biggest thing I want for everybody is to do random stuff.

Go live in Bali for a year.
Try to become the next Beyonce.
Go skateboard, go cook. 
Go try flip life. 
Go put out a song.
It's no different than kissing a bunch of frogs until you find your prince.

10 Brutal Truths About Why LinkedIn Isnâ€™t Working for You
and for 95% of Members who still don't have a Winning Action Plan 

LinkedIn promises to be a goldmine for professionals, but the harsh reality is that it simply doesnâ€™t work for 95% of its members. Why? Because most are making the same fatal mistakes that make all their hard work useless. 

Ready for some tough love? 

1. Desperate Pleas for Success: Your profile screams desperation. Statements like "I need to make this work really fast now" or "I almost run out of money, I need a quick fix" repel potential success. Confidence, not desperation, is key.
 
2. No Repeat Business: If youâ€™re not getting any offline referrals or repeat clients, itâ€™s a clear sign youâ€™re not providing enough value. LinkedIn canâ€™t save a bad business model.

3. Generic Profile: Your profile looks like everyone else's. No unique selling proposition, no compelling story. Just another face in the crowd.

4. Poor Networking Etiquette: Youâ€™re treating LinkedIn like a numbers game, adding connections without engaging meaningfully. Networking is about relationships, not numbers.

5. Inconsistent Activity: Posting once in a blue moon wonâ€™t cut it. Consistency builds visibility and trust. If youâ€™re not showing up regularly, youâ€™re already forgotten.

6. Spammy DMs: Sending generic, copy-pasted messages to potential leads is a surefire way to get ignored. Personalize your outreach, or donâ€™t bother.

7. Lack of Value: If your content isnâ€™t providing value, youâ€™re wasting your time. No one wants to read posts that donâ€™t educate, entertain, or inspire.

8. Overly Formal Tone: LinkedIn is professional, but it doesnâ€™t mean you should be robotic. Show some personality and make genuine connections.
 
9. Not Allocating Time: You think LinkedIn is a quick fix, but it's not. If youâ€™re not willing to allocate time to it, it shows itâ€™s not a priority for you. Building trust and credibility takes time and consistent effort.
 
10. Lack of Clear Call to Action: If youâ€™re not guiding your audience on what to do next, theyâ€™ll do nothing. Always include a clear call to action in your posts and messages.

Too many think they can turn to LinkedInâ„¢, splash around a bit, and the leads will start rolling in. Newsflash! This couldn't be further from the truth.

If you don't have a:

â€¢ unique value proposition
â€¢ strong personal brand
â€¢ active and loyal audience
â€¢ insightful and relevant content strategy
â€¢ engagement & conversion strategy

Then you're basically shouting into the void. 

Now, if you're serious about turning LinkedIn into a lead-generation machine, here are five things that will actually help you get business:

1. Optimize Your Profile: Your profile should be a magnet, not a repellent. Invest time in a professional visuals, a compelling headline, and a powerful summary.
2. Showcase Your Expertise: Publish articles, share industry insights, and give away some of your best advice for free. Make people see you as a go-to resource.
3. Engage Like Crazy: Comment thoughtfully on other posts, join groups, and participate in discussions. The more visible you are, the more connections you'll make.
4. Leverage Recommendations: Ask for and give recommendations. They're the LinkedIn equivalent of gold stars and help build credibility.
5. Personalize Your Outreach: When connecting, send a personalized note explaining why you want to connect. Make it about them, not you.

Remember, LinkedIn is not a magic lead wand. It's a tool. Use it wisely, and you might just turn those crickets into cash.

If you are a parent, could you do me one favour today?
Give your kid a hug, a big kiss, and tell him (s)he is special to you.
For all those people who will never be able to have kids...

Yesterday we lost another pregnancy. A second miscarriage, unexpected but as painful as the first.

Every now and then your kid might be bad, might cause trouble, might cost a lot of energy, or do things you don't like. But never forget the joy they bring, your own flesh and blood growing up beside you in a loving relationship.

Cherish every moment, even the tough ones. Because those moments are gifts. They are fleeting, precious fragments of time that some of us may never get to experience.

For those struggling with loss or the inability to have children, share your pain so your grief is understood, and your strength is admired. 

You are not alone.

And to all the parents out there, hug your little ones a little tighter tonight. They are your miracles. 

Share your love, show your gratitude, and appreciate the gift of parenthood, even in the chaos. Because in the end, it's all worth it.

We'll be alright

Or at least, the term is on life support, hijacked by coaches, C-level execs and business owners who think optimizing their profiles in 30 minutes and churning out three posts a week qualifies them as "thought leaders." It doesn't.

Fact Check:
Thought Leadership isn't just a trendy buzzword; itâ€™s a profound responsibility.

True Thought Leadership is about igniting minds and enlightening communities. It's about more than just sharing expertiseâ€”it's about motivating, guiding, and inspiring people to take meaningful action. True thought leaders build a trusted follower base, not through flashy posts but through genuine, consistent engagement and impactful insights.

9 Types of Clients You Should Fire Today (Even if They Bring in Big Bucks)

Last week, I walked away from a $100k annual deal. Crazy? Maybe. But it was the best decision I've made all year. Hereâ€™s why:

We've all had that clientâ€”the one who makes you rethink your entire career every time their number flashes on your phone.

Not all money is worth the headache. Sometimes, the stress and chaos of dealing with a difficult client simply arenâ€™t worth the paycheck.

So, letâ€™s uncover the 9 types of clients you should have broken up with yesterday. Ready for a laugh (and maybe a reality check)?

My all-time favorite (with a healthy dose of sarcasm) is on slide 10.

But donâ€™t worry, I've also included 6 signs youâ€™re working with the right clients.

My top picks are on slide 15.

The Rogue's Gallery: 9 Clients to Ditch Now

1. The Ghost: Disappears without a trace, leaving you in the lurch just when you need their input the most.
2. The Micromanager: Hires you for your expertise but insists on looking over your shoulder every step of the way.
3. The Non-Payer: Always has a reason why this monthâ€™s payment is delayed. Spoiler: it never gets better.
4. The Scope Creeper: Constantly asking for "just one more thing"â€”without ever wanting to pay for the extra work.
5. The Indecisive: Changes their mind more often than their socks, causing endless revisions and headaches.
6. The Abuser: Thinks that because they pay you, they own you. Hint: they don't.
7. The Know-It-All: Hired you for your expertise but insists they know better. Why did they hire you again?
8. The Freebie Seeker: Always pushing for discounts, freebies, and "just a little help" on the side.
9. The Mismatched Values: Their business practices or values clash with yours, making every interaction uncomfortable.

Laugh, cringe, or maybe even cry a little. But seriously, it's time to re-evaluate. Bad clients donâ€™t just drain your energyâ€”they can also drag your business down.
Remember they should pay you for your unique expertise, not to manage you!

And to balance things out, Iâ€™ve shared 6 signs that youâ€™re working with the right clientsâ€”those gems that make work feel like a joyride.

ğŸ’° How Startup Funding Works
+The Emotional Phases and Ways to Deal With Them

Raising funds and pitching to investors is all about answering:

What does the company do?
What makes it special/unique in some way?
Why is now the time to launch/scale it?
What will it take to succeed?
How big can it grow?
Who are you and your co-founders?

Sounds simple enough.

But for every pitch, every stage, every round, every rejection, and every successâ€¦

There is an emotional rollercoaster that founders need to go through.

1ï¸âƒ£ Anxiety
Itâ€™s easy to get overwhelmed by the 100 things you need to do before you pitch. Anxiety can creep in when you donâ€™t have anyone else to rely on with these things. Get someone you trust to help you.

2ï¸âƒ£ Exhilaration
Itâ€™s good to get excited when meeting investors. But donâ€™t expect them to be on board right away. Itâ€™ll take more than a few meetings to successfully convince an investor.

3ï¸âƒ£ Disappointment
Itâ€™s always hard to find out theyâ€™re not interested to invest. Donâ€™t take it personally. Sometimes, the fund and your startup were just not a good fit. Always call to ask why they rejected you.

4ï¸âƒ£ Hope
All it takes is one to say yes. So you keep moving from one investor to the next. But also remember to nurture and build these relationships. You never know when they could help you in the future.

5ï¸âƒ£ Optimism
Thereâ€™s nothing quite like closing a round and holding that term sheet ready to be signed. But don't jump the gun and spend on offices and new hires without it being a done deal. Also, remember the money is only there to help you grow; you still need to do the hard work to get it done right.

My advice ğŸ‘‰ Before you go raise money, please make sure you have:
âœ” Love at home.
âœ” Good health and lifestyle.
âœ” Time to do what matters most.

Compared to love, health, and time, money has very limited value.

Don't water dead plants. 
 
This idea might seem obvious in your house, but for some reason, many people continue doing it in their businesses. 
 
Of course, you realize that Iâ€™m not literally talking about plants, but rather elements of your company that itâ€™s time to say goodbye to. 
 
Most of us are aware of the fallacy of sunk cost, a cognitive bias that occurs when people make decisions based on the amount of time, money, or resources they have already invested in a particular endeavor, rather than considering the current circumstances and future prospects. 
 
The fallacy is that we believe that because we have already invested significant resources in something, we should continue doing it to justify or recoup our initial investment, even if it no longer makes rational sense to do so. 
 
But to do so is to look at the past rather than the future. 
 
In my work with CEOs, Iâ€™ve seen two types of dead plants that continue to get watered. 
 
First, there are people. Iâ€™ve always believed you should hire slowly and fire quickly. 
 
Harsh? Not really. If youâ€™ve done all you can to help improve a poor performer, itâ€™s time to let them go - for your sake and theirs. 
 
If you allow incompetence to exist in your company, it quickly becomes noticed - and others think itâ€™s acceptable. Nip it in the bud. 
 
The second dead plant Iâ€™ve seen are ideas. We have a (natural!) tendency to fall in love with our own ideas and hold onto them with a death grip. 
 
But prying yourself loose from ideas whose time has passed is incredibly liberating and will open your mind to new possibilities. 
 
Sometimes, you just need some new plants.

When Iâ€™m at my best, 50% of my time is unscheduled.â€ - Steve Jobs

According to Y Combinator, there are 3 phases in a CEOâ€™s role.

Phase 1ï¸âƒ£: Build a great product people love
Phase 2ï¸âƒ£: Scale by delegation
Phase 3ï¸âƒ£: Maximize profits

The second phase is arguably the hardest one for a leader.
Itâ€™s where the most confusion and friction occurs.

Once a company has over 20-30 employees, a CEO must transition from a doer to a leader.

And the best way to do that is through Purpose and Alignment.

You need to be able to define and codify your Mission, Strategy, and Metrics in a way thatâ€™s clear, simple, and inspiring.

Your mission should feel ambitious and permanent.
Your product strategy and GTM strategy should be relevant and updated.
Your metrics should be directly actionable and drives top-line business results.

Now, going back to what Steve Jobs saidâ€¦

In order to clearly define these things, you need to take a step back.

Having a lot of unscheduled think time is perhaps the clearest sign of success for a Phase 2 CEO.

Because you need TIME to think and plan the future of your startup.

What Should Be Derisked at Each Funding Stage?

Fundraising stages are not just about the capital. Theyâ€™re about risk.
Understanding these risks will help you thrive at each stage of your startup.

ğŸš§ Pre-Seed

At this stage, youâ€™re typically not generating revenue. So you need to understand the risks involved with product development and technical debt. Are you optimizing your costs as you build an MVP?

ğŸš§ Seed

At this stage, you need to find your first customers. Who are they and are they willing to pay for your product and service? Investors will wonder if your market is even big enough to generate healthy returns.

ğŸš§ Series A

At this stage, you need a reliable, predictable way of pouring money into customer acquisition. You need an effective go-to-market strategy that can capture your ideal customer segments. 

ğŸš§ Series B

From this point onwards, itâ€™s going to be a high-speed race. A race to capture the most share in the market against bigger competitors. Are you able to expand, scale, and grow to optimize your target market?

ğŸš§ Series C+

This is where founders are tested and turned into strong leaders. Are you able to build a startup culture that can support hundreds of employees? Are you able to maintain the core values you had when there were only a handful in the startup? 

As you move up the fundraising stages, you'll discover the new risks that come with growing your startup.

What most founders realize (sometimes too late) is that they canâ€™t do it alone.

You need a mentor or advisor to help you successfully navigate your startup journey.

Why you need them and what to include â†“

One of the top reasons startups fail is co-founder fallout.

Before you start any company with anyone, please have everything in writing.

It doesnâ€™t matter if theyâ€™re your best friend(s).

They wonâ€™t be when you disagree on:
âš  Profit distribution
âš  Ownership percentages
âš  Decision-making authority

A foundersâ€™ agreement can protect you and the business from crumbling in the future.

Hereâ€™s what you should include:
â€¢ Roles and responsibilities to the company
â€¢ Equity compensation and vesting
â€¢ Salary and working schedule
â€¢ Founder restrictions
â€¢ Intellectual property, moral rights, and non-infringement
â€¢ Confidential information
â€¢ Data Protection
â€¢ Termination and resignation

The key is to map out how the company is run and what actions you can take if a co-founder isnâ€™t acting in the companyâ€™s best interests.

Itâ€™s easy to get caught up in the excitement and hustle of starting a new venture.

Thatâ€™s okay! But be sure to have safeguards in place in case anything happens.

Clients, podcasters and panel hosts often ask me what skills SEOs need to build for the AI future.

For a long time, my answer was to learn, stay open-minded and gain as much practical experience with AI as possible.

Now, my answer is SEOs should learn how to build AI agents and workflows that automate tasks across technical SEO, content generation and data analysis.

AI changes the way search works but also the way SEOs work.

ğŸ‘‘AI raises the value of human content

Context: Training data on the open web becomes increasingly scarce: a new paper shows the growing exclusion of AI crawlers from websites, especially newspapers, social networks and forums.

No wonder: LLM developers make licensing deals with publishers: they need more and fresh content to train new models.

ğŸ¤”Ironically: licensing deals are much more lucrative than selling content directly to end consumers.

ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»Result: human content becomes more valuable as training data for LLMs.

ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»ğŸ‘‰ğŸ»But also: if LLMs continue to rely on human content for trajning and returning up-to-date answers, humans will be needed for a long time.

Good time to be a (good) writer!

You're hosting another webinar. 
The chat's dead silent. 

Half your attendees are probably scrolling through their phones. And you can practically hear people dropping off like flies. 

Sound familiar? It's time to wake the hell up and revolutionize your webinar game.

I've been there. We've all been there. Boring, one-way presentations that put people to sleep faster than a bottle of NyQuil. But in 2024, if your webinars aren't engaging, interactive, and valuable as f*ck, you're wasting everyone's time - including your own.

Here are 5 ways to turn your webinars from snoozefests into can't-miss experiences:

1. Ditch the monologue: Stop talking AT people. Start conversations. Use real-time polls, Q&As, and breakout rooms. Get people involved or get out of the game.

2. Bring the energy: If you're not excited, why the hell should your audience be? Pump up the enthusiasm, use storytelling, and for God's sake, show some personality!

3. Less is more: Cut the fluff. Focus on ONE core message and drill it home. Give people actionable takeaways they can implement immediately.

4. Make it visual: Our brains are wired for visuals. Use dynamic slides, live demos, and even props. Anything to break up the monotony and keep eyes glued to the screen.

5. Create FOMO: Exclusive content, limited-time offers, or guest experts. Give people a reason to show up live instead of watching the recording (if you even offer one).

I remember when we overhauled our webinar strategy at VaynerMedia. We went from typical corporate snoozefests to high-energy, interactive experiences. Attendance shot up. Engagement went through the roof. And most importantly, our audience started getting real, tangible value.

Here's the thing: Webinars aren't just about delivering information. They're about creating experiences that stick with people. That inspire action. That make people feel like they're part of something bigger.

So here's my challenge to you: Take a hard look at your next webinar. Are you truly creating value? Are you engaging your audience in meaningful ways? Or are you just going through the motions?

It's time to step up or step out. The days of boring, one-way webinars are over. Your audience deserves better, and frankly, so do you.

What's one way you're going to make your next webinar more engaging? Drop it in the comments.

I'm going to stop posting on LinkedIn.

Because I feel like a jacka$$ for not having the bandwidth to reply thoughtfully to every comment.

I also feel bad that I don't engage with other's content as much yet they engage with mine.

Dividends on this platform are paid the highest when you support others, not just take from others.

Posting your own stuff without replying back to others, is selfish.

I'm forcing myself to take a month off from LI.

I haven't even been in the best mood and can feel myself nearing negativity.

When I don't feel positive, it isn't fair to write something uninspiring to the audience.

Being selfish on the feed isn't okay.

But drawing boundaries to protect your mental health, is okay.

Every single day, I get people rolling up in my DMs asking me for help.
People just take for granted that I have a business to run, that I'm a founder on 100% commissions and don't have the luxury to give up my time freely anymore.

My DMs are giving me massive anxiety.

And so I'm just going to stay away from LI altogether until my mental health is 100%.

I've helped so many people where it's now become an expectation and get mad that I say no.

Being taken for granted is the emotion that makes me the most bitter.

Not even 5% of the hundred of people, cared to even help me back when I needed it.

It's getting to a point where people don't even care to see how I am / if I need help.

I use to help absolutely anyone; friends, linkedin connections and even strangers with anything.

Now it's taking a toll on me.

Hundred of people have benefited from my immense help, free of charge. But I'm the one left with nothing but bad mental health.

Doing things out of kindness has literally ruined my mental health and stifled my business progress.

My people pleasing days have left the chat.

Signing off so I can be at my best, when I do return.

I don't care how many DMs I have.

I am putting me first.
